title: ‘Ford are grateful to fiery Savage
story: IT was apparent for all to see that Bryansford dedicated this result to their former player and manager, the late great Eamonn Burns.For all the supporters inside St Malachyrsquos Park, this result mattered more than the Brexit vote at Westminster.When the game got underway it was the Hoops who started the brighter. Sean Bell started the ball rolling for the Downpatrick side with a great opening point. However, Bryansfordrsquos sharpshooter Danny Savage, who was to score a spectacular - for his side, levelled the scoring.The RGU then played some scintillating football to take a - to - lead with points from Gerdy Collins , Connor McCarron and Johnnie Bell, who was having a superb game at midfield.Damian Turley, Collins and Tom Smyth were dominating the game and it was dficult to see how Bryansford were going to compete with them.But Savage, a former Down player, kept the lsquoFord in touch with four unanswered points to bring his side within one of the visitors.Another former county player, Packie Downey, was coming more into the game and he levelled the scores with a stunning point from play.Downpatrickrsquos Conor McGrady, another to wear the famous red and black colours, was brought into the game when defender Damian Branf was black carded, putting the RGU in front with a point.Smyth put the Hoops two in front, but the RGU were left stunned when Chris Clarke ended the half with an explosive shot that beat Deeny in the RGU goal to give Bryansford the half-time lead.If the RGU was stunned going into the break, after dominating for long periods in the first half, then after the opening  minutes of the second period, the thought of relegation to Division  was beginning to look a real possibility.Savage scored with with two frees, a  and a rsquo, but then the lsquoFord sharpshooter, with a real opportunist goal, put his side unbelievably six in front.Tim Prenter was then introduced into the game in place of McCarron and with the RGU management urging their players on, they duly responded with points from Branaganand a brace from Conor Doherty to put only one in the game.Conail McNabb was brought on in place of Ruari Quinn and unfortunately only lasted five minutes with a hamstring injury to be replaced by Tommy Loudon.However, with time ticking away, Savage again was the thorn in the RGU side with a  yard free to extend the lead to two.Damian Turley, with a breathtaking score, put the Hoops tantalising only one behind, but Davy McKibben, with a  yard free, put the lsquoFord two ahead again.Try as they could, the Hoops could not mount one last challenge and they were doomed to Division  for next year.Bryansford: M Reid, J Harbinson, S Toner, A Ward, D McDonald, T McAreavey, N OrsquoHiggins, P Downey , D McKibben , C Maginn, K Kavanagh, T Hanna, R OrsquoHiggins, C Clark , D Savage .Downpatrick: J Deeny, P Smyth, D Branf, E Rooney, R Murphy, S Bell , T Smyth , J Bell , D Turley , C McCarron , G Collins , C Doherty , J Branagan , P Turley, R Quinn. Subs: C McGrady for D Branf , T Prenter for C McCarron, C McNabb for R Quinn, T Loudon for C McNabb.Bryansford -Downpatrick -ACFL DIVISION  PLAY-OFF.prettyPhoto

title: ‘Major’ honour
story: ARDGLASS Golf Club has won a stunning accolade.At a glittering awards ceremony in Morocco last week, the beautully manicured links course was hailed the lsquobest Northern Ireland golf experience of the yearrsquo.The club mdash which attracts golfers from across the globe mdash was recognised for the experience it has given visitors over the past  months at the Global Golf Tourism Organisationrsquos th annual awards in Marrakech.The award category this year was focused on recognising the achievements of golf courses and hotels that delivered the best possible experience to visiting golf travellers in the past year.Ardglass officials say that they are delighted with the award and have thanked everyone who helped secure it.Over recent years, the Ardglass club has shared in the European Golf Destination of the Year Award and received further recognition last year when chosen to host the RA British Open Girls Championship.Officials are delighted that the latest accolade is not only a recognition of the scenic and challenging golf course, but the whole visitor experience, arguing that the award represents a further demonstration of how the clubrsquos reputation has spread far beyond local shores.To date this year, the club has welcomed more than , visitors from across the globe and has worked hard to provide the level of service that international golfers demand.The clubrsquos director of golf, Paul Vaughan, said it has had a very successful marketing team at Ardglass over the years, working hard to attract visitors to the course and to build the clubrsquos reputation.ldquoWe also realise the importance of providing a good product when the visitors get here, he continued.ldquoGolfing tourists, particularly those from North America which is a large part of our market, expect high standards of service. We aim to meet these demands by providing a first-class experience in every aspect of their visit.Ardglass captain, Macartan Bryce, said the club is ldquohonoured to have received the award.He added: ldquoArdglass Golf Club is often praised on social media for the friendliness of its welcome and I believe this is down to not only the staff, but to the friendly reception that visitors receive from our members.Local councillor, Dermot Curran, has extended his congratulations to club officials in charge of the course in his home village.ldquoArdglass Golf Club is widely regarded as one of the best in Ireland and consistently attracts golfers from across the globe, he said.ldquoIt plays a key role in helping boost the local economy and I hope that additional visitor accommodation can been provided locally..prettyPhoto

title: Baroness Ritchie of Downpatrick ready to embrace House of Lords
story: FORMER South Down MP Margaret Ritchie will formally take her place in the House of Lords on November .Several weeks ago she was appointed as a Member of the House, something that she regards as a ldquotremendous opportunity for her to re-engage with mainstream politics at a critical time.Her new title will be Baroness Ritchie of Downpatrick, with the former MP explaining that she has chosen her title as it reflects the area where she was born, baptised, educated and spent most of her working le.Elected as a member of the former Down Council in , Miss Ritchie went on to become an MLA, Stormont Social Development Minister, SDLP leader and MP.Her appointment to the House of Lord opens a new chapter for her, one that she plans to embrace on behalf of all of the people of Northern Ireland.Baroness Ritchie firmly believes that where political chambers exist, people should be members of them to reflect the needs of communities across Northern Ireland. She insists that she intends to deliver the authentic voice of moderate, progressive Irish nationalism in a place where it needs to be heard.And she has vowed to be a hard working Peer, lobbying and building alliances with other peers and parties across the chamber that will bring benefit to people in Northern Ireland.And while the former MP regrets no longer being a member of the SDLP, she said her political views have not altered and will reflect the partyrsquos central social democratic messages focused on the needs of people and the principles of equality, fairness and social justice for all in the House of Lords.With her new title now confirmed, Baroness Ritchie described Downpatrick as a ldquohistoric place on the island of Ireland, where St Patrick began and ended his ministry.ldquoThe town is a place of immense heritage and has a longstanding history. It is uniquely associated on the island with the patron saint and is also associated with the Normans and the Vikings, she continued.ldquoDownpatrick is also place of inclusion and a shared society. The area was one of the first to share power at local government level and in the days of the old Urban Council, it had responsibility for allocating housing and did so very much on the basis of need.The Baroness said the Downpatrick area was very much at the vanguard of political inclusion in terms of ensuring that people belonged, explaining that she plans to use her new title to promote the town.Her House of Lords induction takes place on November  with her formal introduction taking place the following day when she will be introduced by her two sponsors on the floor of the chamber.Baroness Ritchiersquos sponsors will be former Northern Ireland Secretary of State, Lord Paul Murphy and Baroness Angela Smith, who is the shadow leader of the Lords.She is also former NIO minister who was responsible for the the health, economy and environment portfolios during her time at Stormont.Lord Murphy was also Minister of State and led the British Government in the talks process that led to the Good Friday Agreement.Baroness Ritchie continued: ldquoI have picked my two sponsors on the basis that while I am going into the House of Lords as non-aligned and independent, my two sponsors understand the mechanics of the Good Friday Agreement and understand inclusion and power-sharing.ldquoMy maiden speech will hopefully take place sometime before the end of the year, although that could be subject to changea general election is called.Looking to the future, the Baroness said she has been using the past few weeks to get briefed on key issues which are important to her, including Brexit and its impact on the agri-food economy and local economy.ldquoTo me, there is no such thing as a good Brexit. The best deal for me is one where we will remain in the EU. What we have been presented with is one that is a bita curatersquos egg in many ways. There will ne no hard border which means no economic border and no veto in terms of the Assembly. Having said that, I am going to have to examine the Brexit deal in greater depth, she continued.ldquoThere are other issues that I want to focus on including the contaminated bloods issue, tourism VAT and what can be done to help our economy and ensure that we can grow and develop. The vaginal mess issue is something I have been associated with as is the importance of the Co Down fishing industry.Baroness Ritchie said while she does not have constituents, she will be speaking in a general Northern Ireland-wide context.ldquoI will be highlighting the importance of reflecting our political ersity and respect for political dference, ensuring that our institutions are up and running and that they respect the relationships between Ireland and Britain and Northern Ireland and the South. Sadly these have been down for nearly three years, she said.The Baroness added: ldquoMy appointment to the House of Lords is an evolution. I was elected to Down Council in , was the organisationrsquos first female chairman, worked as MP Eddie McGradyrsquos parliamentary secretary, became an MLA and MP for South Down and a Minister in the Stormont administration.ldquoIt is now the House of Lords which represents a new challenge and an opportunity which I fully intend to grasp and embrace..prettyPhoto

title: Bid for community centre in Crossgar
story: A CALL has been made for Newry, Mourne and Down Council to keep the pressure on the Department for Communities to fund a new community centre in Crossgar.The village will be left without a building used to host a number community events when the Downpatrick Street property is sold. It is currently on the market.In September, the Recorder revealed news of the planned sale of the building owned by the local Church of the Immaculate Conception and St Joseph.At Monday nightrsquos meeting of the local authorityrsquos Active and Healthy Communities Committee, Rowallane councillor, Billy Walker, raised the issue.He thanked council officials for preparing a report looking at the current community centre provision in Crossgar and the surrounding area.Officials were also asked to contact the government department at a previous committee meeting to seeany finance could be secured to purchase the building which is currently for sale.While officers told the committee that they will be updated in the future should funding opportunities be identied, Cllr Walker, supported by fellow Rowallane councillor Terry Andrews, called for the pressure to be kept up.ldquoI hope that council officers continue to lobby the Department of Communities to secure funding for a new community centre for Crossgar, he said. ldquoI know this will not be an overnight thing but I urge them to keep up the pressure.ldquoThe people of Crossgar are beginning to feel like the poor relation in Rowallane DEA and I believe that the council needs to be seen to be doing its best in this area.Cllr Andrews, who is also the councilrsquos deputy chairman, thanked officials for their report but added: ldquoI think the council still should be trying to get funding from the Department so that Crossgar doesnrsquot have to wait the  years like Saintfield did to get its new centre.ldquoWe have to work together as a team for the people of Crossgar.The committee was told last month that there was no funding for the community centre in the current budget and it would be at least  months before the council could plan for it.The report identied existing neighbouring community centres provided by the council as in Saintfield Community Centre just over five miles away, Ballynahinch Community Centre nearly seven miles away and Killyleaghrsquos Bridge Centre just over four miles away..prettyPhoto

title: Countdown to Ballynahinch Run and Walk event
story: PREPARATIONS are underway for next monthrsquos Ballynahinch Run and Walk To Remember event.Now in its third year and organised by the Ballynahinch branch of The Royal British Legion, it takes place on Saturday, November .The event is organised in partnership with running events company, Atlas Running from Crossgar, and sponsored by Ballynahinchrsquos Primrose Bar and Restaurant.Regularly attracting some of the best club runners from around Northern Ireland, the athletes have recorded some very fast times around the k route since it first started when  runners took part.This year, organisers aim to have  participants and already half of the places are sold out.ldquoThis is an event for everyone to enjoy from families walking the k route together to the serious club runner chasing their new personal best time, said Gareth Armstrong from Ballynahinch RBL.ldquoThe challenging but beautul countryside route has something for everyone, he added.Last yearrsquos race was won by Ballynahinch athlete John Craigin : minutes, with East Down Athletic Clubrsquos Martin Wilcox securing second place in : minutes.Ross Moore of Saintfield Striders crossed the line in : minutes to finish third, while Sarah Graham took first place in the female race where the Mourne Runners athlete clocked : minutes to take the ladies title and claim sixth place overall.Ballynahinch athlete Joanne Fosterfollowed in : minutes , while Albertville Harriersrsquo Beverley Mitchell completing the top three in : .Online entry for the forthcoming event is strongly advised to avoid disappointment by logging on at via www.sientries. Entries close on Thursday, November  and fees are pound for affiliated runners and pound for unaffiliated.All runners and walkers will receive a special one-off Poppy design finishersrsquo medal and there will be trophies for the first three male and female runners to cross the line.And there is also something extra this year as the first  runners to cross the line will receive a free pint of Budweiser Light beer in the Primrose Bar immediately afterwards.All participants will receive a free bottle of water sponsored by Morrisonrsquos Vivo Extra garage located at the Belfast Road in Ballynahinch.Free car parking is available for participants and spectators at Lisburn Street public car park with registration on the day in the RBL Hall between am and .pm.Race assembly is from :pm at The War Memorial..prettyPhoto

title: Down fans to have say on GAA centre of excellence
story: LOCAL people are being given an opportunity to have a say on ambitious plans to develop a major new sports centre for the GAA in Ballykinlar.The proposed multi-million pound centre of excellence facility will include four full size pitches, changing facilities, a fitness studio, multi-use games area, spectator seating, car parking and a new access.The location of the proposed development site is the current Ballykinlar GAA ground at the Commons Road and adjacent land currently owned by the Ministry of Defence.The ambitious proposal is being viewed as not only a signicant boost for gaelic games across the county, but a development that has the potential to kick start the social and economic regeneration of a village which has missed out on funding for many years.Ahead of a formal planning application being lodged, two so-called pre-application public events are being held to spell out the detail of the proposal and for local people to have their say.The events are being held at Ballykinlar GAC clubrooms on Wednesday, November , between pm and pm.A second public event is being held at Pairc Esler in Newry the following day, also between pm and pm.News of the proposed development was outlined over two years ago with the proposal regarded as a ldquomajor game changer for the GAA in Down.No detailed costings are yet available for the ultra-modern facility news of which has has already generated a wave of excitement among clubs across the county.It is understood that GAA officials are in negotiations with the Ministry of Defence to secure a signicant area of land to pave the way for the new centre which will be used by clubs across all Gaelic games codes in Down.The proposed development of part at the Ballykinlar base, which is still used for military and emergency services training, is being described as a ldquomassive boost for gaelic games in the area and a key part of a new vision for the sport in Down.GAA officials have already said thatsuccessful, the Ballykinlar project will form ldquoan important part of a new vision for the county, with the centre catering for the training and administrative needs of Down teams across all Gaelic games codes.Ballykinlar GAC officials have been liaising with Down GAA and revealed that the land which has been earmarked for the new development was previously owned by local people before it was acquired by the MoD.Club officials say that they recognise the signicance of creating a major training base in Ballykinlar, with the planned centre of excellence for the use of gaelic footballers, hurlers, camogie players and lady footballers across the county.Further information about the proposal is available from Resolve Planning and Development, Innovation Factory, Forthriver Business Park,  Springfield Road, Belfast BT DG.Anyone who would like to make comment on the centre of excellence proposal is asked to contact Resolve Planning and Development no later than November .Comments should not be made to Newry, Mourne and Down Council planners. If a planning application is subsequently lodged, normal neighbourhood notication and publicity will be undertaken.At this stage there will be an opportunity to make a formal presentation in relation to the Ballykinlar proposal..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick Lions’ 20th charity calendar on sale
story: DOWNPATRICK Lions Club has officially launched its  calendar.The fabulous new publication features an array of nostalgic photographs of people and places of the town and local area.It is the th calendar to be published by the Lions Club to raise funds for charities and is currently on sale, available from club members and at the Ballymote Centre.The calendar is also available from a number of Downpatrick businesses including Tomrsquos Wine Barrel and Telrsquos Newsagent in St Patrickrsquos Avenue, the Oakley Fayre in Market Street, Flixx Graphics in Irish Street and the St Patrick Centre.Lions officials say the new calendar would make an ideal Christmas gt for friends or family, at home or abroad, and are grateful for the generosity of local people. All monies raised will go towards supporting the clubrsquos ious fundraising initiatives..prettyPhoto

title: Farmers unite with welfare charity over call for hunting ban
story: A NUMBER of local farmers have joined forces with an animal welfare charity to call for a hunting ban.A number of farmers from across the Newry, Mourne and Down Council area met last week with representatives from the League Against Cruel Sports.Those who attended the meeting in Rathfriland say they ldquowant their voices to be heard with farmers discussing the ldquohavoc caused by hunts trespassing on their farmland.During the meeting held last Friday they also examined ways in which to gather evidence to show the scale of the issue.It was claimed that hunts are behind anti-social behaviour and public order offences and that hounds present a ldquobiosecurity threat in the countryside.Farmland being churned up and boundary fencing being damaged were also issued highlighted by farmers.Janice Watt, senior public affairs officer for Northern Ireland at the League Against Cruel Sports, said it is apparent that many farmers are concerned at the behaviour of hunts in the County Down area.ldquoOur aim is to help farmers know the correct course of action to help combat hunt incidents on their land without putting themselves in danger, she explained.Janice claimed that there are ldquohundreds of farmers frustrated by the way the hunts act but who may be afraid of retaliation.ldquoWe will make sure their voices are heard, she continued.ldquoTwenty-first century farms have no need for fox hunting and this was clearly voiced by farmers at the forum meeting. Claiming that farmers need their assistance was the last argument available to hunts. Last weekrsquos meeting has proven that it is not true.The public affairs officer said it is time this ldquobarbaric, unnecessary blood-sport was banned in Northern Ireland which is the only part of the United Kingdom without a ban on hunting with dogs.She said the League Against Cruel Sports is working with local politicians and councillors to highlight the cruelty and the damaging effect it has on rural communities.One of the farmers who attended last weekrsquos meeting said he and his colleagues are ldquofed up with the hunts treating their land as their own.ldquoWe are business people and canrsquot afford the damage caused by this hobby. Alongside the fencing broken by the horses and the crops trampled on, we have had hounds harassing pregnant ewes causing them to abort every lamb lost costs us money, but the hunts donrsquot care, he added..prettyPhoto

title: Father praises charity after twins born at just 36 weeks
story: A NEWCASTLE man has praised the support he received from TinyLe, Northern Irelandrsquos premature baby charity after his identical twins, Alicia and Orla, were born prematurely at just  weeks.Lee Quinn mdash who has also praised the ldquofantastic role the NHS played in the childrenrsquos birth mdash works with the In Car Safety Centre in Belfast and over the years has helped the parents of many premature babies ensure that they are travelling safely.When the identical twins were born, each weighing lb oz, Lee and we Hannah needed that little bit of extra care and support themselves.Lee explained that throughout the pregnancy and birth, the Newcastle couple received fantastic care from the Ulster hospital, with the care continuing after the birth when Lee and Hannah were made aware of Tinyle.ldquoHannah really wanted to breastfeed and with the help of Tinyle and the loan of the hospital grade breast pump, we were able to give our girls the best possible start, Lee explained.ldquoTinyLe also provided a volunteer for a few hours a week which was a massive support, particularly in the early days when the girls were tiny. Hannah also attended a free baby massage class with other parents and premature babies.Lee described the support his family received from TinyLe as ldquosecond to none explaining that Alicia and Orla are now almost a year old, full of le and keeping mum and dad very busy now that they are on the move.TinyLe is also once again inviting everyone to celebrate the signature PREMvember event throughout next month. The event not only marks world prematurity day on November , but also highlights the vital on-going services provided by the charity.PREMvember gives participants the chance to eat cake and raise money for the six premature babies born every day in Northern Ireland, with the successful recipe for the tea party-themed campaign inviting everyone to raise funds with tea and cake throughout the month.Iniduals, community groups, churches and workplaces are welcome to take part and make a dference for families of premature babies.Over , babies are born too soon, too small or too sick in Northern Ireland. Some arrive as early as  weeks, weighing as little as lb  grams, the same weight as half a bag of sugar.The November event continues to engage with the public every year and Elave Baby mdash the certied organic skincare range with lsquoapproved byrsquo status from TinyLe, is supporting the Premvember fundraising campaign for the second year.The companyrsquos chief executive, Joanna Gardiner, said the last thing parents of premature babies need to worry about on top of everything  is what they are putting on their childrsquos skin, explaining that ldquohow young skin is treated can have health implications for the rest of our lives.TinyLe provides practical advice, emotional support and a helping hand to families who have a baby in a neonatal intensive care unit, with their network of family support professionals in every neonatal unit across Northern Ireland, ensuring parents receive optimum support in hospital, at home and within the community.Fundraising packs are provided so throw a tea party, have a cuppa with a friend, organise a huge office tea party or whatever it takes. Large or small, it will make a dference with every penny spent locally through TinyLe.Alternatively,tea and cake is not your thing, other fundraising events are welcome throughout November.For further information on the PREMvember campaign, telephone    or visit www.tinyle.org.uk. Fundraising packs can also be downloaded at www.buytickets.at tinyle.prettyPhoto

title: Former teachers’ union president praises climate activists
story: AS climate protests continue, a local primary teacher has suggested that schools in the area could have their very own Greta Thunberg in the making.Carney Cumper mdash Killyleagh Integrated Primary School vice-principal and Past President of the Ulster Teachersrsquo Union mdash said everyone is always talking about the increasing globalisation of the world in which children are growing up.Mrs Cumper said climate change activists are part of a worldwide movement whose campaign to save the planet has chimed with young people like few other issues in a generation.She continued: ldquoThe fact that our young people are so motivated by the issue is to be welcomed and must not be dismissed with unhelpful sound bites like lsquouncooperative crustiesrsquo.ldquoIndeed, itrsquos a testament to their education that they have the capacity to think these issues through and form opinions. Who knows, Co Down might have its own Greta Thunberg waiting to be discovered.Mrs Cumper said that schools across the area have come up with a range of innovative ideas to address environmental issues, often in a pro-active sense which allows young people not only to make their public protest, but also to be seen to be part of the solution.She explained that at Killyleagh Integrated Primary, pupils are given the chance to talk about climate change, revealing that recently they all walked out of class for  minutes as a gesture of support.ldquoIt was a token gesture but a great opportunity to raise awareness of the issue, Mrs Cumper continued. ldquoI think teachers were enlightened too about some childrenrsquos grasp of the problem sometimes they knew more than us.ldquoThe Northern Ireland curriculum also provides scope for teaching about climate change and how to effectively harness and use protest.The local vice-principal said this ticks the global learning element of the curriculum, focusing on learning how to live in a democracy, how to protest, strike appropriately and about conflict resolution.She added: ldquoThere are many ways our young people can make their point, as well of course as at organised protests. However, the last thing we should be doing is belittling their beliefs or efforts..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C October 23%2C 1979
story: BALLYNAHINCH mdash Ballynahinchrsquos first every triplets took their first bow in front of the camera on Tuesday mdash just four days after being born at the Lagan Valley Hospital in Lisburn.Mum in a million, Mrs Mary Doyle, of  Loughside Drive, gave birth to the three boys just after .am on Friday and all four are doing well and hoping to get home soon.The children were delivered by Caesarian operation, carried out by Mr Bill Sproule, the consultant obstetrician and gynaecologist at the hospital. The first boy weighed lb oz and the other two were lbs each.One of the boys was taken to the Royal Victoria Hospital over the weekend but was ed to his brothers in the incubators at the Lagan Valley on Monday.Mrs Doyle was naturally pleased with the triplets. ldquoIt was a bit of a shock at the time, but I am indeed very pleased. Oddly enough I was unaware that I was going to have triplets until three weeks ago.ldquoThere is no history of triplets in our families, so when my husband Michael and I were told of the possibility of three new arrivals we found it dficult to believe, she said.Mrs Doyle already has three children mdash Eamonn , Madalineand Michellemdash and husband Michael is taking care of them until his we s from hospital.ldquoIt seems strange that Irsquom at home looking after one half of the family while Mary is in hospital with the newly born other half, joked Michael. ldquoSeriously, though, wersquoll have to prepare a nice welcome for all four.Mrs Doyle has already decided on the names for the triples mdash Michael, Gerard and Paul mdash but at the moment doesnrsquot know who will be who.Meanwhile, congratulatory messages and presents have been pouring into the hospital for Mrs Doyle mdash and the Down Recorder joined in the celebrations.Staff photographer Bill Hamilton and reporter PJ Lennon visited her at the hospital on Tuesday and handed over a bouquet of flowers to mark the special occasion.Mrs Doyle, looking pale and tired by extremely happy, expressed her delight at the gesture and sent a message of thanks to all who had sent her congratulations, and all those at the hospital, who had been lsquoabsolutely wonderfulrsquo.ldquoItrsquos unusual to find myself the centre of attrition, but Irsquoll be glad to get home when everything settles down and have a rest mdashthat will be possible now. Everyone seems so helpful, and especially the nursing staff who have taken care of the babies and myself so well.DOWNPATRICK mdash A young Downpatrick mother told this week week of her nightmare le in a Housing Executive bungalow.Mrs Paula Sharvin who lives with her grandmother at Lower Stream Street, explained that she was living in terror of rates coming into her home.This week she found a rat sitting in the coat along with her nine month old daughter, Lesley, and that proved the straw which broke the camelrsquos back for Mrs Sharvin who called in public health officials to try and get something done.She also called in Downpatrick councillor Mr George Flinn to help her in a battle with the Housing Executive toget a new home,safe from the diseasecarrying rats.Le for Mrs Sharvin has been a nightmare since workmen moved onto the marshlandbehind the pre-fabsat Lower Stream Street and started to fill the area in.The rats have swarmed around the pre-fabs with one resident finding seven rats in the kitchen and another discovered them crawling up the toilet in her house.But the conditions which Mrs Sharvin has had to endure are more primitive and because of her fears for the health of her baby daughter le in the pre-fab has become unbearable.The back door at the house has not been opened for over a week, Mrs Sharvin and the rest of the family can not go out the back at night, and windows in the house cannot be opened because of the rats.While there are several bricked up pre-fabs in the area, the Executive have flatly refused to re-house Mrs Sharvin, saying that the homes are not condemned.A spokesman for the Executive explained that their hands were tied, but they were sympathetic with the plight of Mrs Sharvin.SAINTFIELD mdash Fears that up to  employees at Saintfieldrsquos McCleery  LrsquoAmie factory would be paid off this week, have been avoided.Instead there has been an %in the number laid off, with only  men walking out through the factory gates for the last time on Friday.Two months ago the company announced that between  and  men were expected to be laid off, although the managing director of the Saintfield company, Mr R A McKinnon said at the time that they would be trying to save as many jobs as possible.The layoffs on Friday came after several months of discussion between the Trade Union and the management and the general basis for them was lsquolast in, last outrsquo.A spokesman for the firm said yesterday that they were pleased that the lsquomass exodusrsquo which had been feared, did not materialise. He explained that the cutback had been considerably reduced because of lsquonatural wastagersquo.The spokesman added that they were lsquoworking activelyrsquo on trying to save as many jobs as they possibly could but he stressed that the situation changed every day.He also admitted that there were still employees at the factory on redundancy notices, although the company, he said, was hopeful that attempts to revitalise the Saintfield factory would be successful and they pay-offs would not be needed.The lay-offs have been blamed on cheap imports flooding the market, but the company is now concentrating on a new mixed yarn, which they hope should prove more profitable.DRUMAROAD mdash The death took place last Tuesday of Fr James Maxwell, at the Sisters of the Poor Nursing Home, Dublin.Father Maxwell was born in Christmas Day, , in Mullanabane, Ballynahinch. A former Parish Priest of Ely, in the Diocese of Edinburgh, he had been in poor health for quite some time.After leaving his Edinburgh parish Fr Maxwell lived in Portaferry before moving to Blackrock.At his funeral in Drumaroad, Solemn Requiem Mass was celebrated by the Most Rev P McFerran, PP, Newtownards.Concelebrants were Fr G Park, PP Drumaroad Fr G Mary, GP Crossgar Fr J Cosgrove, retired of Motherwell Diocese and Fr S Cahill, Diocesan Adviser.The chanters were the Very Rev Dr Joseph Maguire, PP Downpatrick and the Very Rev P McKavanagh, PP Holywood.Speaking of Fr Maxwellrsquos missionary work, Bishop Monaghan said he joined the Saleian Brothers before taking up residence in the Scottish Diocese.As a curate he had a great influence on the young and had represented many others who had joined the great Irish mission to Scotland in the earlier part of the century.KILLYLEAGH mdash The residents of Killyleagh received a huge pat on the back on Monday evening mdash and it came from two Killyleagh scouts who thanked them for the support they had been given to send them all the way to an International Scot Jamboree in Canada.Clive Scoular, who had the jamboree contingent, and Gordon Jackson, a member of the contingent, were retelling the experiences of their journey of a letime to a big audience at a public meeting in the Lecture Hall, Killyleagh, on Monday evening.With the help of coloured slides and static displays, Clive and Gordon reminded the audience of the  monthsrsquo preparation leading up to the trip, including a parade to Belfast Cathedral and a visit to Lord Elton at Stormont..prettyPhoto

title: Late Siobhan McCann’s family hands out £234k donations
story: FAMILY and friends of the late Siobhan McCann donated a staggering pound, in her name toseven local charities and health groups last weekend.The money was from a charity fund set up to raise funds for lesaving treatment for the much loved Clanaghan woman who was a Gaelic footballer.The donations went to cancer charities and health professionals who are helping people, children and young people live as well as possible with the disease.Siobhan , passed away at her home surrounded by her family in May after receiving some of the immunotherapy treatment that the money was raised for.The former senior ladies player with St Johnrsquos GAC, Drumnaquoile and the Dulwich Harps in London where she previously lived and worked, was diagnosed with colorectal cancer  months before she sadly lost her le.News of her serious illness prompted a massive fundraising initiative by her friends through her home club, which was supported by other Gaelic clubs from all over Ireland and beyond.One of the major initiatives St Johnrsquos organised in conjunction with Castlewellan GAC was a Ladies Sevens tournament last October.A second tournament, involving  teams and won by Castlewellan GAC, was held at St Johnrsquos last Saturday. It was chosen as an appropriate event for Siobhanrsquos family and friends to donate the remainder of the money.Her parents, Brendan and Geraldine McCann, donated the largest cheque of pound, to the MacDermott Unit and MacMillan Cancer at the Ulster Hospital in Dundonald.The money will provide for  chemotherapy chairs costing pound, each, chair accessories such as patient tables and reading lights, nurses stools costing pound each, three computers on wheels costing pound, each and  screens costing pound, each.The Cancer Fund for Children, which runs the Daisy Lodge centre in Newcastle amongst its other initiatives, received the second highest donation of pound,.Presented by Siobhanrsquos sister Grainne Feenan, this money will provide  families with a therapeutic break at Daisy Lodge costing pound, while the rest of the money will be spent funding a range of support sessions for young people living with cancer.Grainnersquos brother Ciaran presented a cheque for pound, to the Friends of the Cancer Centre based at Belfast City Hospital.This money will cover the costs of  complementary therapy sessions for patients and careers and , hours of work for nurse specialists who work at the centre.Siobhanrsquos friends, Alan Henderson and Bria Cunningham, who led the fundraising activities along with Cormac McMullan, presented pound, to the Northern Ireland Hospice.The money will provide for  hours of specialist community hospice care for infants, children and adults to receive palliative care and three syringe drivers which deliver pain relief medication to patients.Friends Keavy OrsquoToole and Aimee Burns presented a pound, cheque to Castlewellan and Newcastle District Nurses to cover the costs of syringedrivers, suction machines and single and double bed sheets used in the treatment of local patients.Siobhanrsquos fellow players, Tara Kilcoyne and Maeve Wylie from Dulwich Harps Girls GAC team, presented pound, to The Little Prince Trust which will provided  real hair wigs to children and young people who have lost their hair through cancer treatment.Past St Johnrsquos GAC chairman, Rory McMullan and senior ladies team representative, Orla Murphy, presented pound, to Donard Family Practice.Proceeds from the sevens tournament and the commemorative Siobhan McCann shirt and charity raffle held on the night will also be donated to the Cancer Fund for Children..prettyPhoto

title: McVeigh boys to the fore
story: WITH a number of dferent races taking place across the province on Saturday, nine Newcastle and District AC members put their toes to the line at the th annual GR race organised by Murlough AC.Starting in Main Street, Dundrum, the . mile race takes runners across an interesting mix of terrains including road, gravel track, boardwalk and beach. As the , runners gathered for the midday start, the weather certainly wasnrsquot in their favour as a number of heavy downpours make the underfoot conditions even more demanding.In case anyone had not already heard in the week he was selected for the Northern Ireland cross country team, Connaire McVeigh was the first Newcastle runner to finish in an impressive . to take sixth place overall and first in his category. The veteran put his strong performance down to the words of wisdom he got pre-race from club cross country captain David OrsquoFlaherty.Second Newcastle runner home was the younger McVeigh, Brian, who managed to take nearly three minutes off his  time to finish th overall in ..Some experienced club members on review of Brianrsquos performance later in the evening point to the dference between him and his older brother in racing terms being mdash the top four inches between the ears.McVeigh responded by claiming he gave his all for the cause and so much so he was forced post-race to visit Artie Quinnrsquos physio table to get a lower limb muscle rub to ensure he was fit for his weekly quarry mast sessions to ensure all the mountain sheep were safe and well.In his first race in a long-time following injury, Paul Byrne put in a fantastic run to finish th overall in .. Paul has been putting in tremendous effort at club training of late and it is great to see him back racing.Following on from her recent Berlin Marathon race a few weeks ago, a brilliant run by Sinead Murtagh saw her finish th overall in .. Sinead, with her performance, managed to take the first lady position which was a fantastic achievement for her and the club.The other Newcastle runners to put their toes to the line and race were Gerard Lawless , Danny OrsquoBoyle , Eamonn Mallon , Fintan McGreevyand our other sole female participant Jacqueline Barbour .The Newcastle runners would like to thank those who braved the autumnal elements to offer support and words of wisdom.Having already had a morning of rugby to feast on, local hotelier Jack OrsquoHare managed to make time in his busy schedule to support the GR race before he had to dash off to Catlewellan to see Bryansford come out on top in their relegation battle against Downpatrick.On reflection, after the game, in The Wine King Bar, Castlewellan, OrsquoHare was seen sipping a well-earned guinness and claimed that the set-pieces were crucial in the rugby and winning more breaking ball was critical for Bryansford to come out on top in the Gaelic..prettyPhoto

title: Murlough trio at Windy City
story: THERE is nothing like running a marathon in the USA,you havenrsquot tried it already I fully recommend it.Last week Carol McMenamin and her sister Orla, Hugh Oram and Charisse Poland jumped onto a plane to Chicago to take on one of the six World Major marathons.This was Carol and Hughrsquos fourth major and Charissersquos first major and second marathon. The three of them were regularly checking the weather in the last few weeks leading up to race day as the temperatures were well up in the high s.Far too hot to be running a marathon, but thankfully in the final week it took a dramaticdown to nine degrees. Flying over on Friday with no time to waste, it was straight to the hotel and then immediately to the Expo to pick up their race numbers and buy some of the many race souvenirs that were on sale.In the Expo there was a wall of fame for all the runners who had completed the six majors. Murlough ACrsquos very own Paula McKibbin and Ann McAlarneyrsquos names were spotted on the wall for all to see.There was no time to get over the six-hours jet lag as they were all up at five in the morning and headed downtown to the start of the km friendship run.This was a bit of fun and involved a quick lap of the city centre finishing in Grant park. The rest of the day was spent in true MAC style with a boat cruise along the Chicago river before dinner in an Italian restaurant.The evening got better as needing a taxi for six people to take them back to the hotel, they managed to acquire the use of a party limousine at a very good rate.Another early start on Sunday as the marathon began at .am in the neighbouring Grant Park. Thankfully, it was only a  minute walk from the hotel. Theyrsquod only just made it into the corrals and the race started.A field of , runners, heading off north through the city, with defending champion Mo Farah expected to retain his title.As the route wound through the city it passed through many dferent districts, all with a party atmosphere and lined with people cheering and screaming encouragement.The noise during a major marathon in the USA is beyond belief, the bands playing, spectators lsquohigh fivingrsquo and the streets lined with people three or four thick is an experience like no other. We passed through the Mexican Quarter with bands playing and guys dancing, wearing sombreros and then on to Chinatownrsquo with the streets lined with drummers.It was then onto the Gay Quarter with drag queens performing on stage. It was a celebration for both runners and spectators.As with all marathons, the last five miles were a real test of mental determination as fatigue kicked in and Carol, unfortunately, was suffering from a knee injury that she picked up during training which ed at mile .They all pushed on with Hugh crossing the line first and recording a new personal best by one and a half minutes. Orla was next home followed by Charisse who recorded a huge personal best of  minutes.Carol was next home and managed to finish in a respectable time as she battled through the final  miles with knee problems. As the runners walked down the street after finishing they were greeted by four lines of local school kids applauding and congratulating all the runners. After the kids there were long tables either side of the street where one of the local sponsors, which happened to be a brewery, handing out free beer. Then onto the next table where they were given food and water.It makes you wonder what is not to like about this marathon  In the ladiesrsquo race a new world record was set as Brigid Kosgei beat Paula Radclfersquos record of  years. Ironically, as Carol finished her race and walked down to collect her medal she was presented with it from no other than Paula herself.It was back to the hotel to get ready for dinner that evening. As Hugh and Charisse walked back they talked about getting a pint of milk each for recovery.As the shop was a ten-minute walk away, Charisse said that even though she knew it would be a bit more expensive she was happy to buy milk for them both in the hotel bar.Being content with the two half pints that the bar served it was only when the bill was produced that they both discovered that they must have drunk the most expensive two glasses of milk ever, with a bill of  dollars. Anything to save tired feet.That evening they continued in MAC style, celebrating with a meal on Cindyrsquos roof top restaurant followed by a few beers in Buddy Guyrsquos Blues bar where we were treated in style with a table in the VIP area. The le of a Murlough AC member is indeed a good one and already planning has begun for the next Major.Meanwhile, the week before, Kieran McShane made the long trek to Australia to complete in the Melbourne Marathon.The race began with an early am start along Batman Avenue in the glorious sunshine. This was Kieranrsquos first big run in over three months due to injuries, so took him a lot longer to finish, but he says it just meant he had more time to take in the lovely views of Melbourne.It was an amazing race from start to finish taking in all the iconic places around Melbourne such as St Paulrsquos Cathedral, Flinders Street, Botanic Gardens and the Shrine of Remembrance.Followed by a lap around the GP circuit then up and down St Kildarsquos beach along the promenade. The finish line was held inside the Melbourne Cricket Ground where the runners had to complete a lap inside the stadium in front of the roaring crowd as they crossed the line in an amazing atmosphere..prettyPhoto

title: Relive the glory days as Down swept all before them to lift Sam Maguire
story: THE countdown is on for a night of nostalgia with the Down  All-Ireland legends when they descend on Loughinisland GAC this Saturday where they will look back at their historic journey which is part of sporting folklore.However, the night will be tinged with sadness after the sudden passing of the former Down and Bryansford star Eamonn Burns, , who won two All-Ireland titles in  and rsquo and managed the county for a three-year spell which ended when he stepped down last year.During that tenure he led his Down team to the  Ulster SFC final with wins over neighbours Armagh and Monaghan.The highlight of Eamonnrsquos career, undoubtedly, was his two points which helped edge out Meath in , including a point which put the Mourne side into a lead they would not relinquish, finishing with a - to - victory.There will be a special tribute on the night to show Eamonnrsquos valuable contribution to Downrsquos glory years.The celebration is to mark the th anniversary of the sidersquos historic win over Dublin in Croke Park during a poignant year for those in the village and surrounding areas.A large contingent of the  Down squad will be in attendance, including captain DJ Kane, lsquoMayobridge Flyerrsquo Mickey Linden, James McCartan, Ross Carr, Downpatrick pair Conor Deegan and Barry Breen, Castlewellanrsquos Gregory McCartan and Ciaran McCabe, Bryansfordrsquos Brian Burns, Carryduff goalkeeper Neil Collins, and, of course, Loughinislandrsquos Gary Mason and Gerard Colgan, plus many more.Compere for the night will be TV and radio personality Frank Mitchell. The popular presenter will bring plenty of fun and laughter to the proceedings.The victory came just three months after the Loughinisland massacre which saw six men murdered in The Height Bar by UVF gunmen while they watched Irelandrsquos - victory over favourites Italy in World Cup on June .The recently-crowned Ulster champions, complete with the Anglo-Celt Cup, came to Macartan Park on July  to play a charity match against a select team of players from Loughinisland, Teconnaught and Drumaness.The local club is hosting the night to thank the squad and backroom team for coming to the village during a time when the people in the area were reeling after the atrocity.Former Down and Loughinisland player Alan Molloy, who joined the Mourne squad shortly after the  final and is one of the organisers, said it was a remarkable feat that a small rural club like Loughinisland had threemedals from the great teams of the s and their achievements had brought much joy and prestige to the club.He added: ldquoThis will be a wonderful opportunity to reminisce with these All-Ireland winners, including Loughinisland men Gary Mason and Gerard Colgan, who gave so much to the county and continue to give so much to our club and community.ldquoGary Mason is the proud owner of two medals, from the victories in  and . Whilst Gerard Colgan was playing for An Riocht in , he spent the last of his playing days with Loughinisland. Both players are now passing on their valuable knowledge to the future generations through coaching our underage teams.ldquoThe club is very grateful that so many legends of the  team are ing to spend this evening with us. This will be a relaxed evening where we can sit back and listen to the enthralling stories from those glory days.ldquoTo honour this fantastic achievement, Loughinisland are delighted to host the Down legends from  in a special evening in our clubrooms.ldquoWe will also take time to remember that  was such a dficult year for Loughinisland. Twenty five years on from the massacre we will reflect on the impact of this Down victory for the community, and the uplt that the team brought.ldquoNot only did the team bring the Anglo-Celt cup, they also came and played at our pitch against a combined Loughinisland, Teconnaught and Drumaness select side, representing all three parishes most impacted. The footballing spirit of the GAA helped the community through these darkest days.The organisers have secured the Sam Maguire and Anglo-Celt cups for the event so there will be opportunities on the night to get photographs taken alongside the Down greats and the iconic silverware.The event will be sponsored by The Irish News and the organising committee would like to thank them for their support and backing.Tickets priced at pound can be purchased in OrsquoToolersquos bar, Loughinisland GAC clubrooms, or by contacting the clubrsquos Facebook page, email loughinislandgac@gmail, or calling  ..prettyPhoto

title: Saintfield out of luck in Intermediate Cup
story: SAINTFIELD United travelled to Seagoe in the first round of the Intermediate Cup on Saturday, but were beaten in a penalty shoot-out.Breezy conditions and a heavy pitch meant that playing attractive, free flowing football would be dficult for both sides.Despite the conditions, Saintfield started quickly, putting the hosts under pressure early on and forcing a few saves from the Seagoe lsquokeeper.But it was the hosts who took the lead with their first attack of the game when the attacker was the first to react to a parried save from Harper to tap home.Saintfield looked to get back on level terms and when James Sofley latched onto a short pass back to the lsquokeeper, he was dragged down unceremoniously and the defender was rightfully shown a straight red card.Saints continued to push and drew level when a familiar corner routine from Ryan Sofley allowed Andy Clarke to smash his ninth goal of the season into the top corner.Soonafter they took the lead when Nick Ross found James Sofley on the edge of the box, and he tucked it into the bottom corner and that completed the scoring in the first half.The second half went back and forth, Saintfield perhaps opting to try the killer pass rather than retaining possession and tiring their depleted opponents and were almost punished when a slip at the back allowed Seagoe a one-on-one with Harper.The attacker beat the lsquokeeper, but couldnrsquot beat Nick Ross who cleared it off the line. But this reprieve was short-lived as the same man got in behind again, but this time finishing well to bring the scores level.Both teams had openings, where a better pass or better cross could have led to a winner, but the game went to extra-time at -.The heavy ground seemed to have taken its toll on both teams as an uneventful  minutes meant the game went to penalties.The hosts scored their first three spot kicks and Saintfield missed their second and third.The Saints scored their fourth and Harper made a save to give the visitors some hope, but the Saints hit the bar with their final penalty to go out of the cup at the first hurdle.Seagoe FC Saintfield United INTERMEDIATE CUP ND ROUND.prettyPhoto

title: Saul pre school praised in inspection report
story: SAUL community pre-school playgroup is celebrating after receiving an encouraging inspection report from the Education and Training Inspectorate.The St Patrickrsquos Road playgroup received the second highest rating of good for quality of learning provision, leadership and management and outcomes for children.Playgroup leader, Delia McLaughlin, took over in September last year only to learn that the school was to have an inspection at the end of her first six months.She explained that staff joined with her working tirelessly over the months, often staying late at night to prepare for the inspection.ldquoWe also had support from our Early Years advisor Megan McConaghy and management committee,Delia explained. ldquoWe are all delighted to have received the second highest rating and are committed to maintaining this standard of the years to come.Accredited by Early Years, the Organisation for Young Children, the playgroup aims to provide quality pre-school care to children aged from two years and  months to four years.Mrs McLoughlin leads a team of play assistants mdash Rita Magorrian, Maureen Fitzsimons, Pauline Carlin and volunteer Niamh Kearney mdash to look after the  children who attend the morning an afternoon sessions.The inspectors noted that the playgrouprsquos provision for The World Around Us and early mathematical experiences were ldquoparticular strengths.The report also noted: ldquoThe quality of interactions between staff and the children is very good. The staff know the children well, engage positively with them and use effective strategies to promote and extend the childrenrsquos language and develop their curiosity.ldquoThe staff implement a range of appropriate strategies to support those children with additional needs. The pre-schoolrsquos approach to care and welfare impacts positively on learning and teaching and outcomes.Education inspectors also highlighted the very good working relationships between staff and children. They said consequently, children appear happy, well settled and are respectful towards adults.The leadership and management of the playgroup is also praised, along with its approach to strengthening its links with home through the lsquoBig bedtime Readrsquo initiative which, the report, noted, ldquohas impacted positively on the outcomes for the children.One of the parents also added her praise: ldquoI cannot express how much the staff of this small rural playgroup work, fundraise and strive to make everyday a special day for the children in their care.ldquoThe challenges they have faced and overcome with fantastic results during the past  months would stun even the most experienced Early Years specialist.The mother added that Saul community pre-school was ldquoessential to the sense of community upheld by the locals and plays an intrinsic part in developing and maintaining the relationships and sense of belonging formed, especially for those children moving onto the local feeder school, St Patrickrsquos Primary..prettyPhoto

title: students young vote referendum hold conference looking life post brexit
story: On Thursday, October , exactly two weeks before the Brexit deadline, Level Three Business students from South West College hosted a non-political student conference where they presented some of the key facts around how student le, and le in general, is likely to be impacted by Brexit.Opening the conference on behalf of her fellow business student colleagues Zanda Rektina said: ldquoSouth West College is the most westerly and one of the most rurally located Colleges of Further and Higher Education in the United Kingdom.ldquoConsidering our location, catchment area in the border region and erse student population, we stand to experience some of the biggest effects from the whole Brexit scenario.During the conference, a number of students led presentations on areas that they believe will be impacted by Brexit including Agriculture and Agri-food, Business and Cross Border Trade, Tourism and Hospitality and Student Le. Leading a presentation on Agriculture and Agri-food, Craig Humes highlighted how dairy farmers will be one of the main farming groups to be ldquostruck by Brexit.ldquo. billion litres of milk are collected from across Northern Irish farms each year.  per cent of this milk produced is then exported south to be processed.ldquoThis could make le extremely dficult for farmersexport tarfs are to be introduced, Craig shared, adding that Dr. Mike Johnston, Chief Executive of the Dairy Council Northern Ireland believes that milk prices could drop by  pence per litre should a no-deal Brexit proceed with such excessive tarfs announced.ldquoIn my opinion, to put it quite simply, dairy farmers will not survive in Fermanagh unless there is a deal, commented Craig.In her presentation on Tourism and Hospitality Rebekah Starrett noted how Fermanagh had over , visitors last year who spent an average of pound. million.ldquoThis is a massive amount of money being spent in this local economy. The tourism and hospitality industry here supports , jobs ndash one of the biggest employment sectors in the county.ldquoIf Brexit happens it could mean some businesses may need to let some staff go and leave people without a job, said Rebekah.Stating that in her opinion Brexit offers the tourism and hospitality sector many innovative opportunities to potentially grow and expand, Rebekah shared some examples.ldquoThere has been a rise in lsquostaycationrsquo ndash the number of UK residents that have been staying and holidaying at homehas shown a three per cent rise in  and is continuing to grow something which would be good for Fermanagh Tourism, explained Rebekah, who also highlighted how Fermanagh is renowned for its celebrity chefs, award-winning restaurants and local produce which will continue to attract visitors to the County.Presenting facts on Business and Cross Border Trade, Nicole McFarlane and Oran OrsquoLoughlin shared how Enniskillen has the lsquotop performing ASDA store in the UKrsquo which was the th best store in Walmart Worldwide Group in  and that an average shopping trip spend by Republic of Ireland shoppers to Enniskillen is euro to euro.ldquoCross Border trade stands at pound. billion for  and Northern Ireland makes up between  to  per cent of total exports from Ireland to the UK and accounts for seven to eight per cent of imports, stated Nicole and Oran, adding that the flow of trade between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland will depend on what kind of agreement replaces the current one which is free market trade within the EU. Sharing a positive outlook on how Brexit could impact business trade, the studentsrsquo stated: ldquoBrexit could actually result in more opportunities in more vibrant markets across the world becoming available. Some argue that Brexit could liberate the UK government to sign fresh trade deals with more dynamic markets outside the EU and therefore bolster trade.Whilst presenting his research on how Brexit could impact Student Le, Jordan McClure shared: ldquoStudent le is a vital part of growing up where we learn many things. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. Issue date: Wednesday Feblt spangtlt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentE-CIGARETTE use is rising across Wales and more tobacco smokers are quitting the habit.The figures revealed in a YouGov survey by Action on Smoking and HealthWales reflect the growth in e-cigarette use across Great Britain, where nearly half as many people vape as smoke.New data published by ASH shows that there are now an estimated . million vapers compared to . million smokers in Britain.In Wales seven per cent of the adult population now vape, compared to  per cent that smoke. This compares to five per cent of the population in , when  per cent of adults smoked.However, there has also been an increase in the numbers of ex-smokers who now vape.:The National Survey for Wales shows that, in ,  per cent of e-cigarettes users also smoked cigarettes. This fell to  per cent in  .Across the UK the number of vapers who are ex-smokers reached . per cent in  with the main reason given for using e-cigarettes being to help them quit.Of those surveyed by ASH Wales,  per cent of e-cigarette users cited health as their main reason for vaping.Suzanne Cass, chief executive of ASH Wales said: ldquoThe rise in the numbers of ex-smokers who now vape in Wales shows that many smokers are using e-cigarettes to quit.ldquoIndeed, when coupled with behavioural support e-cigarettes have been shown to be one of the most effective ways to give up smoking, enabling thousands of smokers in Wales to break a habit that destroys lives.ldquoHowever, with more than double the amount of people in Wales smoking compared to vaping, we still face a major challenge when it comes to changing peoplersquos behaviour and de-normalising what has become an entrenched habit in many of our most deprived communities.Despite the increase in the number of people vaping, the survey also revealed perceptions of the relative harm of e-cigarettes compared to tobacco cigarettes have worsened.Now almost a third of people in Wales believe e-cigarettes are equally or more harmful than tobacco cigarettes.Suzanne Cass said: ldquoThere is work to be done when it comes to raising awareness of the relative harm of e-cigarettes compared to tobacco cigarettes and addressing concerns about the safety of vaping.Since the survey was carried out, reports of a possible link between e-cigarette use and deaths from lung disease in America have led some medical experts to warn of the dangers of vaping.According to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention many of those vapers affected had used products with liquids containing cannabinoid products.E-cigarettes are regulated in the UK in line with a set of European-wide rules by the medicines regulator, the MHRA. The MHRA also monitors adverse reactions through its yellow card system, which to date has not identied serious respiratory problems similar to that found in the US.Meanwhile vapers in the UK are urged by ASH to only ever purchase e-cigarettes from reputable suppliers. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: vale film fest host oscar winner world record attempt
story: Peter Swords King, who won the Oscar and a BAFTA for his work in the Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit trilogies, will run a talk and masterclass for enthusiasts as part of the festivalrsquos finale. His portfolio also includes Disneyrsquos Pirates of the Caribbean and Mary Poppins Returns.The masterclass offers fans the opportunity to immerse themselves in the artistrsquos work and to learn about dferent make-up genres and elements of screen production. The class will conclude with a question and answer session.Lynn McFarlane from Dresd Studios said: ldquoHe is at the core of film making and under his guidance, the audience will be privy to an in-depth knowledge of production unique to his experience.Families, friends and film buffs alike are invited to partake in a Guinness World Record attempt at the worldrsquos biggest quiz, which will include around  competitors. Players will be immersed in props, sets and costumes from popular TV shows and films.The festival runs from September  to October  and will see a iety of events taking place across unique Vale locations.Both events take place on October  at Dresd Studios in St Athan.This project has received funding through the Vale council and the Wales Rural Development Programme, which is funded by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the Welsh Government.The creative rural communities team, part of the Vale council, has been working closely with communities and businesses in the rural Vale to help bring this event to le.The aim of the pilot is to assess interest in provision of a film festival that celebrates film and unique venues in rural communities across the county.More information, including booking tickets can be found at: https:www.valefilmfest whats-on  article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Picture: Vaughan ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtGething AMlt spangtlt spangt" Penarth ‘climate strikers’ say why they marched on the SeneddClimate protestors on the march" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentNEARLY  protestors from Penarth made clear their concerns over climate change as part of a global ldquoclimate strike day.Armed with placards and banners, activists young and old sang and chanted as they marched from Penarth to the Senedd on Friday.Thousands of activists protested across Wales, with strikers marching to the Senedd in Cardf and taking over the council chambers in Swansea.The Penarth march was co-organised by Dr Eleanor Kean, of Penarth.Dr Kean said: ldquoI counted  people in our group as we went onto the barrage. We were a mix of young people, parents and other concerned citizens of Penarth, and met outside Grfin Books.ldquoWe joined the young people who have been striking from school. In a year this movement has grown from Greta Thunberg by herself to millions worldwide.ldquoThe evidence on climate change is clear. Our actions through burning fossil fuels and demands for continued economic growth cause global warming and climate change. People are already suffering and nature, upon which we all depend, is collapsing. Governments need to be honest about this and act upon the crisis.ldquoWe were over the moon with the response from Penarth residents, who walked with us or cheered us on, the day really gave us hope that the message is seeping in and change can happen. Myself and others had been feeling quite down because climate change is scary, we are worried about our childrenrsquos futures. Lets hope this walk leads to more local action on climate change.The young people on the march also spoke about their concerns.ldquoI went on strike because people cut down rainforests just to be able to eat meat, said seven-year-old Mylo Kitchiner. ldquoIf we keep cutting down trees we wonrsquot have oxygen to breath. I want the government to stop people cutting down trees. I liked the chanting, lsquoclimate justice nowrsquo but this is not just fun to shout, itrsquos actually really important.Sister Lily-Rose Kitchiner, , said: ldquoPeople in places like Africa suffer because of how we live here and it needs to stop. The government needs to do more to stop climate change.ldquoI donrsquot know why we have to tell them this, why donrsquot they think itrsquos important Penarth resident and leader of Wales Green Party, Anthony Slaughter, also attended the march. He said: "The massive turnout for the climate strike march in Cardf showed the strength of feeling from all sections of our community on the ongoing crisis and the impacts already being felt across the world."While people of all ages were present, this was a day when young voices were prominent with speaker after speaker articulating their generations anger at government inertia. This was a day for politicians to listen and take real, meaningful action to tackle the climate emergency."Business as usual is no longer an option."The Welsh Government has declared a ldquoclimate emergency and set a target to cut carbon emission by  per cent by .Millions of people across the globe have joined the strikes, with major cities brought to a stand-still.Greta Thunberg, the -year-old who sparked the movement with a solitary protest outside Swedish parliament in August  tweeted: ldquoChange is coming. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
